TopicTitle: Devnote Tuesdays: The Forward Progress Edition

Articles.Content:
<p><img alt="image" src="https://31.media.tumblr.com/0ff9377afa68dc3ad3fe6844aaf1bd38/tumblr_inline_n2aqocY4iD1rr2wit.jpg"/></p>

<p><strong><img src="https://31.media.tumblr.com/d55cf2021863b7c6ba92ac56ae13ed94/tumblr_inline_n2at93g7ml1rr2wit.png"/></strong></p>

Felipe (HarvesteR): Settling back in at home after a very intense but really awesome time at SXSW. WeÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re gearing up to start the last push on development for the ARM update, which I must say is coming together really nicely, and IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m even more excited about it after meeting up with the guys from NASA and getting to talk about our and their asteroid missions.

<p><strong>Alex (aLeXmOrA): </strong><span>IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve been helping with some other Squad projects here at the office, since IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m also the Web Administrator of the company. For <em>KSP</em>, I started working on a system that will show us stats of how far the players have gone in the game. </span></p>

<p><strong>Marco (Samsonart):</strong><span> IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve been trying various approaches for the NASA guided mission, itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s been kicking my ass pretty much all week, thus the need for a guided mission.</span></p>

<p><strong>Chad (C7)</strong><span><strong>:</strong> WeÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re working with NASA to refine the rocket parts that will be included in the new update. I spent some time preparing some explanatory notes that will be useful for NASA during the revision and editing process. ItÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s been a dream come true working with NASA and I really enjoyed meeting several members of their team in person at SXSW this past weekend, including Jason Kessler and Jason Townsend, who were on our panel, as well as Doug Ellison from the JPL team. </span></p>

<p><strong>Daniel (danRosas)</strong><span><strong>:</strong> Only one more sequence to render! And a couple of shots to re-render from the one that I left over the weekendÃ¢â‚¬Â¦ I forgot to animate some extras in the background, and they look a little frozen heh. After that, itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s all in for color correction, a couple of motions for some UI that will appear in various shots and the final sound design by our sound designer Edu. Also, IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m helping Romfarer with some animations for the Mission Control that are not cooperating. And I foresee some video editing for Max by the end of the week.</span></p>

<p><strong>Jim (Romfarer):</strong><span> </span><span>This week i have been reviewing the logos submitted for the manufacturer logo competition in an attempt to narrow down the lists. All in all we received 1,297 logos and it will take a while to select the winners. IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve also continued working on the application launcher and added better mod support for it.</span></p>

<p><strong>Miguel (Maxmaps): </strong><span>Pumped to work on stuff for GDC, otherwise been neck deep in the tutorial process (Yay, 3 hour mission to realize your craft was built wrong) and working on a voiceover for our SXSW video. Attempted to do it in Dr. Seuss rhymes, felt ashamed with the result and had to start from scratch.</span><span></span></p>

<p><strong>Jesus (Chuchito): </strong><span>After testing the KSP Server on OSX 10.8.5 , Linux Slackware 14.1 x64 and Windows Professional SP1 x64, IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m developing the chat system.</span><span></span></p>

<p><strong>Bob (Calisker): </strong><span>Wrapping up a great time at SXSW, including the opportunity to moderate our panel at the Gaming Expo with NASA and C7 and Harv. Getting ready for GDC next week, which is pretty exciting as IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ll be talking about how communities are now integral in creating the brands for games during the main conference and C7 is sharing details on modular design in </span><span>KSP</span><span> during the Independent Games Summit. WeÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ll also be conducting some meetings throughout the week, watching some other folks sessions and trying to enjoy San Francisco. </span></p>

<p><strong>Ted (Ted): </strong><span>Continuing QA on the NASA pack with the QA team. The pack is really coming together and the QA team and I are incredibly amazed at the content that it contains. Many, many hours of fun and/or testing has been had with it so far (and a few bugs, but theyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re swiftly being stamped out).</span></p>

<p><span><strong>Anthony (Rowsdower):</strong> In addition to the usual community rounds, IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m neck deep in word docs and on a semi-related note, been helping out with some media pitching for GDC. Speaking of which, have you seen <a href="http://bit.ly/1iaGGcC"><strong>THIS</strong></a> thread? IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m gauging interest on a low-key, unofficial GDC meetup. ThereÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s no guarantee that itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢d happen, but you live in the bay area and/or youÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ll be around at GDC, vote and let me know your interest. It would be good to know for potential meetups elsewhere, too.<br/></span></p>

<p><strong>Eduardo (Lalo):</strong><span> Making some internal reports of development advances.</span></p>

Edited March 12, 2014 by Rowsdower
Added HarvesteR's comments.

First post!

awesome progress Squad - you guys rock!
Ah, Devnote Tuesdays! How can you not love 'em?

Marco (Samsonart): IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve been trying various approaches for the NASA guided mission, itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s been kicking my ass pretty much all week, thus the need for a guided mission.

Hmm. So it's sounding like this won't be a mission we can plan and fly ourselves, but will have aspects controlled by the game?

Devs, we dieing in excitement and quriosity. Please post more images or even a video. We really would like to see what happening with the update.

Also, can someone from the devs tell how much an asteroid (Min/Max) weight? I want to use the asteroid mod to get some experience before The release of 0.24. Thanks

Edited March 12, 2014 by greg12
Yay! Everything is awesome!

Hmm. So it's sounding like this won't be a mission we can plan and fly ourselves, but will have aspects controlled by the game?

He's making a tutorial actually.

We have tutorials for flying to the Mun, which is much much easier than this mission. But we can still do it (and even figure it out) all by ourselves in the game. So why should we not have a tutorial for a really difficult asteroid rendezvous?

Thank you for you HARD work guys!

And may the asteroid intercept concept saves the world someday.

Hope the guided mission is just a tutorial Am I the only one having a problem with Rowsdower's link?

Btw don't let it become a habbit to do dev notes without Harvester !

This is the correct link.

Can't wait to see these new parts you're so pumped about, guys.
No HarvesteR update? That's odd. Any hope for a more detailed post from him later?

He's making a tutorial actually.

Ah! That's a relief.

Btw don't let it become a habit to do dev notes without Harvester !

Got this from the facebook page.

...I was expecting late-march.

So...

NEXT WEEK?

..just kidding, don't take this as serious. Good work everyone!

Hmm. So it's sounding like this won't be a mission we can plan and fly ourselves, but will have aspects controlled by the game?

My thought was that it'd give you hints somehow. And I also got the impression that there was the Nasa Mission thing to do something specific, and then also that there would now be asteroids in the game that we could do with what we wanted. With those sweet, sweet robot arms I can't wait to try out.

No HarvesteR update? That's odd. Any hope for a more detailed post from him later?

Well if last week is any indication then yes. If you define "later" as "some time in the future, though not necessarily this week or next. Or any week, really. Okay, no. We won't hear from him."

But really, if we aren't getting updates because he's working on something awesome and top secret (or just awesome and very time consuming) then I'm cool with that.

Can't give dates yet, but far sooner than you think.
Got this from the facebook page.

I would be amazed if the post/reply immediately after that wasn't 'I think now!' or words to that effect.

I would be amazed if the post/reply immediately after that wasn't 'I think now!' or words to that effect.

Oh yeah! Looks like i better free up my calendar!
You win a no prize, NoMrBond. Got that taken care of in the first sentence haha.

"Jim (Romfarer): This week i have been reviewing the logos submitted for the manufacturer logo competition in an attempt to narrow down the lists. All in all we received 1,297 logos and it will take a while to select the winners. ..."

Let's see, if each contestant entered one logo for each company, there'd be about 48 contestants. On the other hand, if each contestant only submitted a single logo, there'd be 1297 contestants. Its possible that some contestants did more than one logo per company. If we average the 48 and 1297, that would make it about 673 contestants. If we consider those that did multiple logos per company, the figure might be around 600 contestants. Wow!

Edit: if we go with 10% of active forum members, the figure would be more like 500 contestants. /Edit.

But no matter what the actual figures are, 1297 logos are a lot to go through. :-O

Good luck on the judging and to the contestants!

Edited March 12, 2014 by Dispatcher
Another guess at the number of beans in the jar.
HarvesteR's comments have been added.
